Package projects.graph

Class Graph

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.graph.Graph
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    AdjacencyListGraph, AdjacencyMatrixGraph, SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph
    public abstract class Graph
extends java.lang.Object

    Graph is an abstraction over directed and weighted graphs. It supports insertion of nodes, insertion and removal of edges, queries of connectedness, simple accessors, as well as shortest path computation. The weights are non-negative and are bounded above by the field INFINITY.

    Nodes in Graph are simplistic in that they are characterized just by an increasing index. So, the first node inserted would be considered node 0 (zero), the second one node 1 and so on and so forth. For this reason, removal of nodes from a Graph instance is not supported, otherwise inconsistencies with the internal representation of the instance could occur. For example, if we have 8 nodes and we remove the first one inserted, should we consider a new node to have index 9 or 8? It's unclear, so we just let go of the requirement.

    Author:
    Jason Filippou
    See Also:
    AdjacencyMatrixGraph, SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph, AdjacencyListGraph

        public static final int INFINITY

        A named constant that describes infinity. Useful for shortest path computation.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Graph

        public Graph()

    • Method Detail

      • addNode

        public abstract void addNode()

        Add a new node to the graph. The node will be characterized by its index of insertion, such that the first time this method is called, a node with index ' 0 ' is stored in the graph, the second one we will store a node with index ' 1 ', etc, etc.

      • addEdge

        public abstract void addEdge​(int source,
                             int dest,
                             int weight)
                      throws java.lang.RuntimeException

        Adds an edge from node source to node dest in the graph, attaching to it weight equal to weight. In this implementation, we don't allow weights to be negative. If a weight that is either negative or greater than INFINITY is provided, the method should throw a RuntimeException. If the edge already exists, its weight should be updated to the parameter value.

        If either source or dest don't exist in the graph, the behavior is undefined. This means that you can do whatever you want, as long as you don't store extra edges or nodes in the graph. You can throw a RuntimeException, return null, print a message, anything. We do not test for this case.

        We treat the addition of a weight with zero weight exactly the same way we would treat the deletion of an edge through deleteEdge(int, int). So, the calls add(i, j, 0) and deleteEdge(i, j) are equivalent.

        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        dest - The "sink" node of the edge.
        weight - The weight of the edge.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - if weight < 0 or weight > INFINITY

      • deleteEdge

        public abstract void deleteEdge​(int source,
                                int dest)

        Delete the edge from source to dest. If the edge does not exist, or if either node does not exist in the graph, no action should be performed.

        We would like to particularly stress that removing an edge does not in any way imply removing its constituent nodes, even if the nodes end up being singleton disconnected components!

        Parameters:
        source - The "source" node of the edge.
        dest - The "sink" node of the edge.

      • edgeBetween

        public abstract boolean edgeBetween​(int source,
                                    int dest)

        Queries the graph about the existence of an edge from source to dest. If either source or dest are not contained by the graph, then the edge itself cannot possibly exist and the method should return false.

        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        dest - The " sink " of the edge.
        Returns:
        true if, and only if, source, dest and the edge source->dest all exist in the graph, false otherwise.

      • getEdgeWeight

        public abstract int getEdgeWeight​(int source,
                                  int dest)

        Returns the weight of the edge source->dest. If the edge does not exist (either because at least one of the two nodes does not exist or because they both exist but there is no edge between them), this method should return 0.

        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        dest - The " sink " of the edge.
        Returns:
        the weight of the edge source->dest

      • getNeighbors

        public abstract java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> getNeighbors​(int node)

        Retrieves the "neighbor" nodes of the provided node, i.e all the nodes to which it points. If the node does not exist in the graph, the behavior is undefined; you can do whatever you want (and that helps you debug!) and we don't test for it. If the node does exist in the graph but it has no neighbors, the returned Set should be non-null, but empty (size 0).

        Parameters:
        node - The node to retrieve the neighbors of.
        Returns:
        A Set of all nodes to which node points.

      • getNumNodes

        public abstract int getNumNodes()

        Retrieves the number of nodes in the graph.

        Returns:
        the number of nodes in the graph.

      • getNumEdges

        public abstract int getNumEdges()

        Retrieves the number of edges in the graph.

        Returns:
        the number of edges in the graph.

      • clear

        public abstract void clear()
        Clears the graph of all its nodes and edges, resulting in an empty graph.

      • shortestPath

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> shortestPath​(int source,
                                                      int dest)

        Returns the shortest path between source and dest in the graph, where the shortest path is defined as the path with a minimal sum of weights of the constituent edges. Since we don't allow negative weight edges, you can implement this with Dijkstra's, Bellman-Ford or Johnson's algorithm, whichever one you prefer!

        Shortest path computation only requires methods of Graph's interface (i.e the other public methods). For this reason, defining it only once, in the base class, is the best approach. This does, however, require that Graph is made into an abstract class instead of an interface.

        Notes:

        1. The code will have to be your own. No taking ready-made libraries out there, whether they are part of Oracle's standard library or not. However, if you choose to implement Dijkstra's algorithm, you are allowed to use a third-party implementation of a priority queue, which is a data structure required for an efficient implementation of Dijkstra's. You can also use other ready-made data structures, such as hash tables or lists.
        2. If either source or dest are not part of the graph, the behavior is undefined (we don't test for this case).
        3. Since Graph represents directed graphs, even if source == dest, there may not exist a path that connects source and dest.
        4. If there is no path from source to dest, the list reference returned should be non-null, but the list itself should be completely empty.
        5. We do not test you on < source, dest > pairs for which there exists more than one shortest paths, so your implementation can handle such cases in whichever way it wants.
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        dest - The " sink " node of the edge.
        Returns:
        An ordered List whose first (head) element is source, the last (tail) element is dest and all the intermediate nodes make up the path from source to dest.
